Yes, CO2-catalyzed N-formylation of aliphatic amines with DMF Xiao-Chao Chen Lin Guo Guang-Hui Shi Kai-Chun Zhao Yong Lu Ye Liu ⁎ Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, School of Chemistry & Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, Shanghai 200062, PR China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes School of Chemistry & Molecular Engineering East China Normal University Shanghai 200062 PR China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, School of Chemistry & Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, Shanghai 200062, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Carbon dioxide (CO2) was found to serve as a novel and green catalyst for the first time in N-formylation of amines with N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), wherein only the aliphatic amines were applicable to afford the formamides in the yield of 71∼95%. The isotope labeling experiment with DMF-d 7 indicated that the N-formyl group in the formylated product was originated from DMF rather than CO2. The control experiments and the in situ high-pressure FT-IR spectra demonstrated that the formation of the carbamate salt of cyclohexylammonium cyclohexylcarbamate (A) derived from the reaction of CO2 with cyclohexylamine was the driving force for this reaction. Accordingly, the mechanism of CO2-catalyed N-formylation of aliphatic amines with DMF was proposed, involving the formation of carbamate salt intermediate with enhanced nucleophilicity in anion in favor of the attack on carbonyl-group of DMF. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 catalyst N-formylation Formylating reagents in situ high-pressure FT-IR spectra Carbamate salt 1 Introduction Utilization of carbon dioxide (CO2) has attracted great attention due to the environmental and ecological issues arising from CO2-emmission [1,2]. Based on the prevailing interaction between amines and CO2 to form carbamate salts in the form of [RR'NH2][RR'NCOO] (which require organic catalysts including ionic liquids for its stabilization), the built-in CO2 in the [RR'NH2][RR'NCOO] is utilized as sustainable C1-building block in the functionalization of NH bonds over different catalysts to yield important intermediate compounds such as N-formamides, N-methylamines, carbamates or aminals [2–4]. Therein, N-formamides are important chemicals in various syntheses of pharmaceutical products ike 1,2-dihydroquinolines [5], substituted aryl imidazoles [6], N-heterocycles [7], fluoroquinolines [8] etc. N-formylation is the typical route for preparation of N-formamides through the catalytic reaction of organic amines with different formylating reagents [9], including formic acid or its derivatives [10–16] [Scheme 1 -(a)], CO [17–20] [Scheme 1-(b)], CO2/H2 [21–25] [Scheme 1-(c)], CO2/hydrosilanes [26–29] [Scheme 1-(d)], or DMF [30,31] [Scheme 1-(e)]. Therein, CO2 along with the reductants of H2 or hydrosilanes has been considered as one of the attractive formylating source. Even under catalyst-free condition at room temperature, the formylation of amines by using CO2/hydrosilanes to the corresponding formamides was achieved as reported pioneeringly by F. W. Li et al. [29]. In addition, N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) is also a widely applied formylating reagent in organic synthesis as employed in Vilsmeier-Haack reaction. It is also noted that the non-catalytic N-formylation of aliphatic amines with DMF has been reported in 1973 by M. A. Kraus [32], which suffered from the harsh reaction conditions (∼30 h, ∼150 °C) and poor chemoselectivity. Hence, N-formylation of (aliphatic/aromatic) amines by DMF is commonly conducted in the presence of various homogeneous [33–36] or heterogenous catalysts [37,38]. Herein, for the first time, we presented a new methodology for N-formylation of aliphatic amines with DMF (or DEF), wherein CO2 was able to serve as an efficient and clean catalyst for the synthesis of N-formamides under mild reaction conditions. The catalysis of CO2 was convinced by the control experiments, isotope-labeling method, and in situ high-pressure FT-IR spectra. Although the chemical transformations of CO2 have been widely explored [2–4], the exploit of CO2 as a catalyst has rarely been considered before. To date, this work is the first example to define CO2 as an efficient catalyst in the specific chemical reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and analysis The chemical reagents were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd and Alfa Aesar Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd (China), which were used as received. All the solvents were dried and distilled before use. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ARX 500 spectrometer at ambient temperature. Gas chromatography (GC) analysis was performed on a SHIMADZU-2014 equipped with a DM-Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). GC-Mass spectrometry (GC–MS) which equipped with a DB-Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) was recorded on an Agilent 6890 instrument equipped with an Agilent 5973 mass selective detector. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS 670 spectrometer. Thermogravimentry/differential thermogravimetry (TG/DTG) analysis was performed on a TGA2(SF) from Mettler Toledo. 2.2 General procedures for N-formylation of aliphatic amine by DMF In a typical experiment, DMF (3.0 mL) and aliphatic amine (3 mmol) were added into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The obtained mixture was sealed and pressured by CO2 (0.5 MPa). Then the reaction mixture in the autoclave was stirred vigorously at appointed conditions. Upon completion, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature and slowly depressurized. The reaction solution was analyzed by GC to determine the yields of the N-formylated products with n-dodecane as internal standard, which was calibrated by the commercial sample of formamide. The products were further identified by GC-Mass spectrometer. 2.3 Preparation of the carbamate salt of A Cyclohexylamine (10.0 mmol) was added into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave which was sealed and pressured by CO2 (1.0 MPa). Then the reaction mixture was stirred vigorously at room temperature for 4 h. Upon completion, the autoclave was slowly depressurized and then a white solid was collected as A, which was characterized by 1H/13C NMR spectrometer. 1H NMR (500 MHz, D2O, δ, ppm): 1.06–1.19 (1H), 1.24–1.36 (4H), 1.60–1.72 (1H), 1.73–1.86 (2H), 1.89–1.96 (2H), 2.96–3.11 (1H, s); 13C NMR (δ, ppm): 23.92, 24.43, 25.14, 33.18, 33.25, 50.45, 164.71 ppm. 2.4 Characterization by in situ high-pressure FT-IR spectrometer for reaction of CO2 with cyclohexylamine vs reaction of CO2 with aniline The in situ high-pressure FT-IR spectra were recorded by the Nicolet NEXUS 670 spectrometer. The spectral resolution was about 4 cm−1. Firstly, 25 µL cyclohexylamine was added in the specially designed high-pressure IR cell, in which cylindric CaF2 was used as the sealing sheets. Secondly, the FT-IR cell was purged with CO2 (0.2 MPa) for three times. Finally, under the CO2 atmosphere, the real time monitoring was recorded by the FT-IR spectrometer. 3 Results and discussion Initially, the N-formylation of cyclohexylamine with DMF with the presence of CO2 was investigated as a model reaction under the different conditions (Table 1 ). It was shown that, without the presence of any auxiliary additive or co-solvent, the yield of N-cyclohexylformamide increased obviously from 73% to 91% in 12 h when the temperature was increased from 80 °C to 100 °C (Table 1, entry 2 vs 1). Further increase of the temperature to 120 °C had no effect on the product yield. At 100 °C, nearly the same yields (92∼93%) were obtained in 9 h and 12 h respectively (Entry 4 vs 2). But the shortened reaction time of 6 h led to the decreased yield (Entry 5 vs 4). Hence, 9 h and 100 °C were selected as the optima conditions for the next experiments. Evidently, CO2-presence and CO2-pressured dramatically affect the product yields. Without the presence of CO2, the product yield dropped to 9% (Entry 10). With the presence of CO2, the highest yield of 95% was obtained under CO2-pressure of 0.5 MPa (Entry 7). The further increase or decrease in CO2-pressure obviously depressed the reaction rate (Entries 6,8,9 vs 7). It was noticed that no product was detected when DMF was replaced by DMSO (Entry 11), indicating that DMF rather than CO2 was the real formylating reagent. When aniline was applied in place of cyclohexylamine, no reaction happened either (Entry 12). Accordingly, the optimal conditions (100 °C, 9 h, CO2 0.5 MPa, DMF) were selected as applied in Entry 7. With the optimized conditions in hand (100 °C, CO2 0.5 MPa, DMF as formylating reagent and solvent), the evolution profiles of cyclohexylamine conversion along with formation of N-cyclohexylformamide against reaction time were presented in Fig. 1. It was demonstrated that the conversion of cyclohexylamine rapidly increased from 14% (1 h) to 93% (9 h) always with 100% selectivity of N-cyclohexylformamide. Further prolonged reaction time from 9 to 15 h just led to 4% increase of cyclohexylamine conversion up to 97%. The control experiments in Scheme 2 -(1) indicated that when the deuterated DMF-d7 was applied instead of common DMF, the target N-cyclohexylformamide with m/z of 128 was obtained in the yield of 95% under the same conditions applied in Entry 7 of Table 1, which further confirmed that DMF rather than CO2 served as the formylating reagent in the reaction. In addition, when the as-synthesized carbamate salt of A was applied as the starting material to react with DMF, N-cyclohexylformamide was obtained in the yield of 95% under atmospheric CO2 [Scheme 2-(2)]. In contrast, in N2 atmosphere, the reaction of A with DMF just led to 27% yield of N-cyclohexylformamide [Scheme 2-(3)], due to the rapid decomposition of A at the reaction temperature of 100 °C without CO2-protection as shown in TG/DTG analysis in N2 flow (Fig. 2). These results (Table 1 and Scheme 1) reveal that (1) the formyl group in the product of N-cyclohexylformamide is originated from DMF, (2) the available carbamate salt of A with fair stability under suitable CO2-pressure is the active intermediate for the N-formylation of cyclohexylamine, and (3) the real catalyst is CO2 which is involved in the reaction to expedite the reaction rate and then regenerated intactly. In addition, the in situ high-pressure FT-IR spectroscopic characterization for reaction of cyclohexylamine with CO2 [39] further convinced that once CO2 (0.2 MPa) was introduced to react with cyclohexylamine, the carbamate salt A was formed immediately with indication of the characteristic peaks at ca. 3401 and 3305 cm−1 (attributed to the N⊕H3-characteristic vibrations) as well as the multiple peaks around ∼1625 cm−1 (assigned to carbonyl vibrations) with reference to the as-synthesized sample of A [Fig. 3-a-(2) vs Fig. 3-a-(1)]. When N2 was introduced to expel CO2 gas, the already formed A was fairly stable which didn't undergo decomposition as shown in Fig. 2-a-(1). In comparison, when CO2 was introduced into aniline with weak basicity (Fig. 3-b), there was no reaction at all between aniline and CO2 to form the required carbamate salt with catalytic activity, corresponding to no formation of N-formanilide as depicted in Entry 12 of Table 1. These results (Table 1, Scheme 2, Fig. 2 and Fig. 3) verified that only the aliphatic amines with strong basicity (i.e., nucleophilicity) could form the fairly stable carbamate salts. Accordingly, the mechanism of N-formylation of aliphatic amines with DMF catalyzed by CO2 was proposed in Scheme 3 . When CO2 is introduced in the reaction, the carbamate salt intermediate (denoted as A-analogue) as the CO2-amine adduct (i.e., catalyst-substrate adduct) was formed immediately. As for A-analogue, the nucleophilicity of N-site in the anion of A-analogue is stronger than that of amine (R1R2NH) due to p-π conjugated effect, which facilitates the attacks of N-atom to carbonyl group of DMF to reach the transition state of B, along with the release of one molecule amine (R1R2NH). Subsequently, B undergoes the eliminating reaction to yield the target product of formamides, accompanied by the regeneration of CO2 catalyst. The scope of substrates for this CO2-catalyzed N-formylation of amines with DMF (or DEF) were investigated in Table 2 . In general, as for the primary or secondary aliphatic amines, the target formamides were obtained in good to excellent yields of 81∼95% (Entries 1–12). Notably, as for the diamines such as piperazine and 1,6-hexanediamine, only the corresponding di-formamides were obtained with good yields of 74∼81% (Entries 8 and 9). In case of 1,6-hexanediamine, the prolonged reaction time of 24 h was required to give 74% yield of the diformamide (Entry 9). In Entries 11 and 12, when chiral amines were subjected as the starting material to the reaction, 90% and 85% yields of the formamides were obtained respectively. In contrast, as for aniline with weak basicity, the N-formylation didn't happen due to the failed formation of the required carbamate salt intermediate of A-analogue (Entry 13), which had been convinced by the in situ high-pressure FT-IR spectroscopic analysis (Fig. 3). The use of DEF (N,N-dimethylacetamide) instead of DMF as the formylating reagent to repeat the reaction just resulted in the decreased yield (71%) for the target product of N-cyclohexylformamide (Entry 14 vs 1), due to the bulky steric hindrance of DEF and then the hindered accessibility to intermediate A-analogue as depicted in Scheme 3. 4 Conclusion CO2-catalyzed N-formylation of aliphatic amines with DMF (or DEF) to afford N-formamides has been developed under mild reaction conditions (CO2 0.5 MPa, 100 °C, 9 h). It was proved that DMF served as the formylating reagent while CO2 as a catalyst upon forming the fairly stable carbamate salt (A-analogue) with the aliphatic amine. In this salt intermediate (considered as an CO2-amine adduct), the N-site became more nucleophilic than amine substrate itself, facilitating the nucleophilic attack of N-atom on carbonyl-group of DMF to rapidly yield the N-formylated products. It is encouraging to point out that CO2, which is commonly regarded as an inert gas, is able to play important catalytic role in some chemical transformations. coredata.dc:description: Carbon dioxide (CO2) was found to serve as a novel and green catalyst for the first time in N-formylation of amines with N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), wherein only the aliphatic amines were applicable to afford the formamides in the yield of 71∼95%. The isotope labeling experiment with DMF-d 7 indicated that the N-formyl group in the formylated product was originated from DMF rather than CO2. The control experiments and the in situ high-pressure FT-IR spectra demonstrated that the formation of the carbamate salt of cyclohexylammonium cyclohexylcarbamate (A) derived from the reaction of CO2 with cyclohexylamine was the driving force for this reaction. Accordingly, the mechanism of CO2-catalyed N-formylation of aliphatic amines with DMF was proposed, involving the formation of carbamate salt intermediate with enhanced nucleophilicity in anion in favor of the attack on carbonyl-group of DMF.
coredata.dc:title: Can CO2 be a catalyst? Yes, CO2-catalyzed N-formylation of aliphatic amines with DMF
